millsfield:images_texts:
Wind velocity, gustiness and turbulence.
Considering the entire period of observation, the greatest
average wind velocity occurred at Site No. 2, with Site No. 5,
Sites Nos. 1, 4 and 6 and Site No. 3 following in order.
The
provalling winds blew with greater average volooity at both
Site No. 3 and Site No. 5 than at Sites Nos. 1, 4 and 6, but ex-
treme velocities of 30, 35 and 40 miles per hour or more were
recorded a greater number of times at Sites Nos. 1, 4 and 6 than
at Site No. 5. Everything considered, Site No. 5 1s as windy as
Sites Ilos. 1, 4 and 6 and Site No. 2 1s even more so.
The least
average wind volocity and the greatest freedon from high winds
were found at Site No. 3.
Although the lightest average winds and greatest freedom
from high wind velocities were found at Site No. 3, the winds
there were very gusty, decidedly more so than at any of the other
suggested sites.
Gustiness was greater at Site No. 2 then at any
of the others with the exception of Site No. 3 and there was little
difference botween Sites Nos. 1, 4 and 6 and Site No. 5, the latter
having a slight advantage.
Investigation of turbulence in the first 1000 feet above the
ground revealed practloally identical conditions at Site No, 3
and Site No. 6, and less favorablo conditions over the other
proposed locations.
Procipitation and Temperature.
Precipitation, the no remaining meteorological element
for which comparative data were obtained, did not very between
-1-

the several proposed sits by any considerable amount.
Neither
the precipitation data in Table 19 nor the temperaturo data in
Table 20 have any important bearing on airport location within
the aroa under consideration but they will be found to have
other practical applications.
Conditions Summarized.
From the consideration of data that have been presented,
1t 1s obvious that Site No. 6 (Ills Fleld)* has an advantage
over all other proposed sites in freedon from fog, visability, ceil-
ing, and constoney of wind direction. Moreover, the prevailing
wind direction at Site No. 6 (Ills Meld*) 1s such that the majority
of take-offs may be made over favorable territory, which cennot be
sald for any other proposed site, excepting No. 4 (adjoining and to
the south of mills Floid*). In fact, dopartures may be made in any
direction from Site No. 6 (1411s Flela*) with favorable conditions
for an emergenoy landing in the proximity of the airport should
occasion require 1t.
It was also found that the variation in wind direction from
moment to moment at site No. 6 (Mills Pleld*) was less than at any
other proposed site except No. 2 (South San Francisco*).
The surface
wind velocity at Site No. 6 (Ills Fold) was found to be more
(South S.F.*)
advantageous for the operation of aircraft then at Site No. 2/and
equally with Site No. 5 (Pt. San Mateo*), although smaller average
wind velocities and greater freedom from high winds occured at
Site No. 3 (Berestord*). The latter site, however, has a distinet
disadvantage on acoount of exoossive gustiness, en ovil from
which a& site No. 6 (Alls Pleld) 1s relatively free. No other pro-
posed site had less turbulence in the lower levels of the er than
Sito No. 6 (31118 Pleld)* while, above 1000 feet, smother air was
NOTE: *words in perenthesis do not ocour in text.

indicated over Site No. 6 (Ills Field*) then over any of the others,
Site Recommended.
Site No. 6 (Ills Field) the location of the present temporery
airport, is therefore reco mended as a result of the meteorolorical
survey as the most suitable one for the permanent location of
the San Franoisco Municipal Alrport.
All factors considered,
no other suggested site appears to have as favorable meteorological
conditions as this one.
The present site of the San Frand soo lunicipal Airport
Includes a small portion of Site No. 4 (adjoining and to the south
of Mills Field*), and, should it becone advisable to extend the
boundarios of the present airport in a north-south direction, the
survey shoms that the extension should be to the southward.
leteorological conditions over Site No. 2 (South Son Francisco*)
preclude extension in that direction as they indicate more fog,
lomer ceilings, poorer visability, higher wind veloities and more
turbulence than are found over the present site of the sirport and
the area immediately south thereof.
